reviewText: I almost hate to say this show is the best episodic drama series ever produced because it is so subjective and so difficult for any show to live up to such praise, but DAMMIT "The Wire" IS the best television drama I have ever seen.  Every season has been magnificent and Season 4 more than held its own with previous seasons.  I have never seen such consistently good writing, direction, and acting in a television program, whether it appeared on cable or broadcast t.v., and Season 4 of the show has a particularly powerful impact because of its unblinking focus on the sad and often doomed lives of so many of our children living in our inner-cities.  I cannot wait for this box set to come out so I can complete my Wire collection, and I am so looking forward to the start of Season 5 in January.

The fourth season of HBO's critically acclaimed The Wire picks up after the explosive events the conclusion to the third season, as cop Jimmy McNulty (Dominic West) finds himself patroling the streets of Baltimore and seemingly out of the loop (McNulty is relegated to more of a supporting player in these episodes than ever before) as this season focuses on the coming election between Mayor Royce (Glynn Turman) and Tommy Carcetti (Aidan Gillen), and a group of young corner kids getting ready to go back to school.  What makes this season of The Wire so surprisingly compelling isn't the drama between the cops and the crooks like we've seen before, but what this group of young corner boys (Maestro Harrell, Julito McCullum, Tristan Wilds) experience and the choices they make, which not only effect their own lives, but inexplicably effect the lives of everyone else involved as well.  In the meantime, new kingpin Marlo (Jamie Hector) makes even more of an impact as the cops try to nail him, Herc (Domenick Lombardozzi) finally gets his stripes, Prez (Jim True-Frost) becomes a teacher, and Omar (Michael K. Williams) gets in over his head when he goes toe to toe with Marlo.  By the end of season four, it is apparent that the end is near, and that McNulty and his crew are sitting on a powder keg that will be as explosive as anything that has ever been seen on HBO.  Undoubtedly one of the finest and most realistic TV dramas ever crafted, The Wire is once again spectacular entertainment.

If you have seen The Wire in its previous three seasons and wondered whether this one measures up, the answer is "absolutely yes".  If you haven't seen the show at all, what are you waiting for?

Previously I would've said season 2 was my favorite, but I think this one surpassed it.  It is astonishing to me that the show gets better and better.  We continue to see deeper facets of characters we are familiar with, and we get a group of new ones that become vividly etched in our consciousness very quickly.  Pat Moran Casting in Baltimore deserves an award for consistently finding strong actors for the show, including for this season, a good-sized group of early teens and younger.

"The Wire" IS the great American novel that so many have talked about writing "some day".  David Simon and his fellow scribes were driven to paint a realistic gritty portrait about life in a contemporary American industrial city and we have all reaped the rewards.

I agree in sentiment with the people below me in that The Wire is incredible and I understand that they want to talk to someone about what happens in it.

Please don't give a synopsis of what happens - this isn't what the review system here is for.

I recognise my hypocrisy as I'm not using it for it's intended use either but please don't come here to account for the events of Season 4 when people who haven't bought it may be coming here to purchase it.

Cheers.

The story so far... (Don't read any further if you don't want to know any detail of what happens in this Season of the show).

On street level, Stringer Bell is dead, Avon Barksdale is back behind bars and the cold and wilful Marlo Stansfield (played by Jamie Hector) looks like he's squaring up to be crowned king. Preston "Bodie" Broadus (played by JD Williams) is the only true Barksdale soldier still holding it down but finds it's a whole new game with a whole new set of rules. Meanwhile, the drug dealers' nightmare that is Omar (played by Michael K Williams) has a new protg in tow and he's as busy as ever. The scene when he and Marlo finally come face to face is pure TV heaven.

On law level, political involvement in the Major Crimes Unit sends its best personnel off in all different directions: Lieutenant Daniels (played by Lance Reddick) gets promoted out, Detectives Kima Greggs (played by Sonja Sohn) and Lester Freamon (played by Clarke Peters) are squeezed out - and back to Homicide - and Detective Jimmy McNulty (played by Dominic West) realises he's running the risk of losing his soul and goes back on patrol. He also gives up the booze and tries to become a family man. The end result of all this is that no one is really up on the wire and by the time the incredible number of bodies being stacked up in vacant houses by Marlo's two lieutenants Chris and Snoop (played by Gbenga Akinnagbe and Felicia Pearson) come to light, there are so many of them, the task of solving the crimes seem pretty much unsurmountable to the shocked law enforcement personnel.

On City Hall level, Councilman Tommy Carcetti (played by Aiden Gillen) does the unimaginable and wins the mayoral elections in Baltimore but finds it might be the beginning of his battles rather than the end.

And if all that were not enough, in the middle school system, the 'No Child Left Behind' programme is shown up for what it really is, while 8th graders - some, like Michael (played by Tristan Wilds) and Dukie (played by Jermaine Hawkins) with drug addicted parents; some, like Namond Brice (played by Julito McCullum) with drug dealing parents - dad Wee-Bey (played by Hassan Johnson) is in prison and mother De'Londa (played by Sandi McCree) wants her little boy to grow up and be just like his daddy - and tragically, some with no parents at all - Randy (played by Maestro Harrell) is in foster care and Sherrod (played by Rashad Orange) is taken under wing by Bubbles (played by Andre Royo) of all people - are left to their own devices and to the lure of the streets. Some of the younger kids like the streetwise and smart-mouthed Kenard (played by Thuliso Dingwall) and the car-stealing, joy-riding Donut, so small he can barely see over the steering wheels of the cars he jacks (played by Nathan Corbett), we don't get to see their parents at all. Ever.

And this is not even the half of it. The scene is thus set for the fourth season of this incredibly articulate HBO series and on many levels, primarily due to the focus of school-age children, it might prove to be the most explosive season of all. With its awesome ensemble cast, "The Wire" continues to draw the highest praise from the most unexpected of quarters all over the world. Don't miss this. And don't let the complex storylines, unglamorous settings or gritty (and often violent) scenes and colourful language put you off. It's like watching real life or reading a novel. In the real world, situations do not usually get resolved within 50 minutes, just as they don't get tied up neatly within a chapter of a book. It was appointment TV for me on the FX channel earlier this year and I so cannot wait for the DVD. This is without a doubt, the best thing on TV.

PS. I've deliberately refrained from using the B word because I've come to understand that it upsets certain people and I totally understand why.

We could be missing the point though, with the utmost respect. The stories that are being told here - and they are just stories by the way; "The Wire" is not a documentary series or even a docudrama - could be told from Washington DC, Miami, Los Angeles, Philadelphia, Detroit or any major US city and still be just as authentic, and just as believable. I don't believe The Wire is a statement about a particular city. I think the creators and writers have just gone with the location they know - and love, it has to be said.

I don't feel it's a statement about America either, particularly. Drug addiction, drug wars (the so-called wars being fought against drugs and the wars the drug dealers are contantly fighting amongst themselves), the proliferation of guns in our communities, political corruption and, (as is highlighted in this particular season), deficient child educational systems in particular and the way children are collectively being failed by the very society that is supposed to protect and nurture them in general, are all evident all over the world if we know where to look.

IMO, these are stories about human nature and the different ways in which man's actions affect the world we live in. That's what makes "The Wire" so fascinating.

The fourth season of The Wire can easily hold its own against the first and third seasons.  I thought it was very good and was hooked on it since the first episode, I can not wait until it is released on dvd.

The Wire is simply one of the best TV series ever.  Maybe even the best. I'm especially partial to Season 4 because it deals with our kids and our education system.  We see these 4 boys' school experience, home experience, and street experience.  We see the way that they're supported and failed by the adults in their lives.  These boys make some good and bad choices; but alot of choices and decisions are made for them--sometimes by adults who themselves were failed when they were young.  I was especially moved by the character Duquan.  What chance does this kid have to grow?  I mean, someone helps him out here and there.  But no one really looks out for him.  These kids are just screwed by the system, although there are some adults who intervene to try to help.  Naimond gets a really lucky break.  Each boy in The Wire Season 4 has a story, and you understand the kind of adult he'll probably turn out to be based on the traumas and triumphs of his childhood.  Season 4 is just simply brilliant.  The entire series is stellar.
My favorite season!

season 4, episode 3
  episode starts with a gem of a scene....  morning time,  omar ventures out to the little store in his satin jammies and robe to get cereal and smokes. Headed back home, he stops, leans on a building and lights a smoke.  THUD - a plastic garbage bag plops down next to him from above. he looks at it and takes it home...and of course it was the stash..
  he ripped and meandered?  The scene was handled softly..no big deal made of it is but is very funny in it's own dark way.

The Wire is a gritty and gripping detective drama, which is widely considered to be one of the all-time best shows in this genre, as well as being one of the greatest television programs ever made. It was created and primarily written by David Simon, the renowned author and former crime reporter, who, because of his background, was able to impart an uncanny sense of realism to the series. The Wire was set and produced in Baltimore, Maryland, and its story line centers around the organization and function of the criminal drug trade in Baltimore, and the tragic way in which it has ravaged the city, and its beleaguered residents. The Wire consists of a total of sixty episodes, spanning five seasons, with a different emphasis for each season. Although the multifaceted drug trade represents the overarching focus of this series, each individual season assesses the manner in which this criminal enterprise impacts a specific operational area of the city of Baltimore. The first season of The Wire examines the drug trade itself, the second season deals with the dysfunctional seaport system, the third season analyzes the corrupt city government and bureaucracy, the fourth season addresses the deteriorating school system, and the fifth and final season evaluates the unethical print news media. It brutally and realistically depicts the devastating effects that the criminal narcotic trade has had on the residents of inner city Baltimore, whose lives have been destroyed by the pervasive drug-related misery, despair, and hopelessness, which have now become endemic in this population. The Wire is characterized by insightful and brilliant writing, superb plot and character development, and absolutely spectacular acting performances, by its exceedingly talented ensemble cast. It definitely deserves the numerous awards and accolades which it has received over its five-year run. The Wire is a truly outstanding television series, which is riveting, moving, and emotional, and it merits an unequivocal five-star rating, along with a very strong recommendation.

The deconstruction of a major American city continues. The promise of a "new day" by the new mayor is in danger from the "old hustlers". Some of the police attempt to investigate drug related murders and others go along to get along. But new problems are coming. No spoilers.

This series came out in the 2002 - 2008 years. Seem to recall it got a number of awards for its depiction of the drugs, unions, police and politics in the City of Baltimore. But probably not much difference in our other large cities.

It's a mess and has been a mess in our cities for a long time. Will it ever get better? Not certain it will-its too engrained into the day-to-day as shown in this series.

You watch this and then pick up the news and you see it happening as this show showcased it years ago.  If our new President can break this cycle up starting in Chicago and be successful, it will change these cities and the people who live in them and give them some hope.

The show depicts the lives impacted by this crummy environment they have to live in. A great show to binge watch and watch again every few years as I did.

What has been done in the past has not worked and The Wire shows this with characters, some who carry over from season to season. You see it with the drug dealers, the cops who in some cases get tainted by bending the rules to stay alive and to make progress, to local politician whose goals are " to look good" for their next election.

Yep its a mess, but maybe-just maybe there is a small sliver of hope. Lots of violence, profanity, occaisional nudity so a adult only show. But it is a really good show.

As in previous seasons, it is amazing how little is left to the imagination in presenting the grittiness of the lives portrayed and situations encountered. One can't help but grow to love some of the characters in spite of their clear faults, and to despise some of those that intentionally abuse their positions of power at every opportunity or are too stupid to recognize the negative consequences of their actions. This season focuses on the subject of education of the neighborhood youth, both in the schools and in less formal environments such as the local gym or the streets. Many of our previously appearing favorite characters are back, but nothing is the same. There is not a dull moment in any episode.

This series is one of the best TV has to offer. The social issues are well researched and depicted in a most interesting and engaging manner. You feel torn between empathy for the folks who find themselves amongst the disenfranchised, and unable to condone the criminal acts which seem to be a way of life. The cast has many talented actors. I am not surprised that many of them now appear on the Bosch series. I would recommend this series to everyone who wants to get a glimpse of life and predicament of inner city America.

Good series. At first I did not like it, as it was a bit confusing, but the longer I watched, the more enthralled I became.  I had to use the captions because I could not understand what the characters were saying.  I know this is "just" a movie/TV series  -- meaning, it is Hollywood, not necessarily "REAL" life -- but I found the cultural perspective very thought provoking.  I came away understanding a bit more of the utter hopelessness that the "inner-city" inhabitants are exposed to --- I had a friend tell me I was "White Privileged".  I have been chewing on that for weeks now. My gut reaction was -- "heh, I worked hard to get where I am, my parents worked hard to provide my education, etc."...but it is deeper than that. I am still processing that label, along with how  the characters in the series were portrayed.  I feel there is much work to be done to make things better.  But, as far as the series goes, well worth the watch.  I am hoping the level of corruption in the police department and the city government is just a Hollywood portrayal -- I pray that is not the case in real life.  If so, we really have some work to do and people need to own this.

The Wire is the best show ever created for television. Season four is likely the best season of the show.
The corner boys theme shows us another public institution (schools)  that has surrendered to bureaucratic pressure and is juking the stats and pushing kids through the system, not with malice, but with frustration. Teachers take solace in small victories while losing the overall war.
The election reveals another side of a corrupt system and an "ends justify the means" mentality.
So, so much more. The rise of Marlo, Cutty's continuing redemption story, Chris and Snoop (the nail gun scene is classic), Omar, Bubbles, Dukie, Michael. So much great stuff packed in one season. You have to watch The Wire altogether, though. A friend described it as a tapestry that only really makes sense when viewed as a completed work of art.

I thought the series could have ended here, although I would also have liked it to go on . . . theoretically . . . forever.  I think the series was best when it focused on the people in the street . . . drug dealers, cops, teachers and the kids that have to grow up among the relentless and unnecessary chronic tragedy of our inner cities.  The funny thing about the concept of "chronic" and "tragedy" is that when something is "chronic" we get used to it and it doesn't seem like a tragedy anymore.  The Wire makes it clear that there is such a thing as a "chronic tragedy."  Yet it does this with objectivity, compassion and humor.  Interesting that the truth is actually more entertaining than the canned stuff.  (By the way I work on death penalty cases investigating the social history of the accused, and this series is right on the money, if a bit more grandiose for the sake of art.) This season is as good as it gets on TV.  Keep in mind that I already watched the whole season when it first aired.  This is like rereading a favorite book and realizing once again how great it was, and how it will probably never come again.

It as amazing. I didn't see this series when it first aired almost 10 years ago but, boy oh boy, I'm glad I finally got a chance to see it. It's not just another story about people living in the hood. This series was so well done. It required a lot of research on the part of the writers to capture, not just the plight of a community engulfed in the drug trade but, the politics surrounding it and the fact that the drug trade is truly a trickle up economy. People you'd least expect relied on the income from the sales just to make ends meet and hold failing industries together.

The acting was also superb. I credit the acting as the reason that it was so easy to get immersed in the storyline.  I didn't feel as though there was a single character that didn't belong. You got to know them, care about them, anticipate their demise, or rally in their corner. Above all, this show touched on the reasons that people in the inner cities live the way they do. They have been excluded from the progress that went on around them for so long that in many cases they don't know how to change the direction of their lives. It was powerful.

Recently my wife and I started with the first episode of season one. Watching one or two episodes a night we've managed to completely view season one-three and are well into season four. Season four is good, but does not compare to the earlier seasons. The show is called "The Wire" not how to solve all the problems of the inter-city. The political aspects of all seasons is discouraging. From the crooked major to the in-component police chief down to the dumb head daily patrol officers. Its like a few good guys are rowing upstream against all the obstacles being placed in front of them. This situation likely is mirrored through all the federal agencies. Look how tainted the FBI has become.

Best television show ever and whatever is second isn't all that close. Season 4 focuses on the school system and is an extremely realistic portrayal of inner city kids; outstanding production, acting is all first class, editing and pacing are a genuine pleasure to watch. I have seen all five seasons now several times and it just gets better every time. Story lines are so complex that it requires multiple viewings to catch everything that's going on. Breaking Bad is very well done; this is in a class by itself.

Seasons 1 & 2 were the best. I really came to care for and feel frustrated by the situation the characters are put in and their weak attempts to escape those situations. I could have done without some of the graphic sex scenes that are totally unnecessary and didn't forward the story. I was glad that this fell to the wayside by season 3 and 4 however, these seasons were slow for me and fell into too much tedium for the average viewer. I realize they were showing the frustrations of the school system and they really did bring home the red tape and inefficient bureaucracy for me with the slow story line. I felt like I was living it minute by minute rather than watching a tv show. Season five picks back up and ends on a better note with several characters seeming to have a brighter futures. However, you get the sense that this is a never-ending system of flaws because the components that made it work originally have failed. Truth, honor, justice, reputation, ethics, morality...neither neighborhoods, schools or the justice system can work without these human characteristics and traits.  much anymore. This isn't about poverty or just a simple lack of opportunity because people were poor in the 1920's and they did not commit these kinds of ruthless crimes against each other.

We have stopped teaching and training up young people in the way they should go.
This show is gritty and adicting, I'm going to be sad when I finish season 5.
My favorite season of all five. It is a great depiction of the struggle of inner city kids and the school system and foster system that fails them.

Repeatedly doing the same thing while expecting a different result - definition of pure insanity.

The detour to the school system is well done. The season ending finale, while superbly written, comes off as a bit too predictable. All in all, though, The Wire season 4 is a worthy addition to one of the best shows of recent years

Each season of this remarkable series shines a light on another aspect of the environment and lives of its characters.  Season 4 takes us into the education system - and shows us the conflict between educators and the politicized Board of Education.  We learned that schools, too, play a numbers game, and that 'juking the stats' isn't the exclusive province of the Police - and the waste of human lives and potential continues.  The game changes, drug dealers adapt, people die and it all goes on.  Amazing work - writing, acting, directing - all of it.

The stories continue to be so well acted and written with a truth and an intensity that cannot be matched. All the episodes seamlessly incorporate life on the mean streets of Baltimore, black and white political power games, the private and public lives of the beleaguered police, the teenage struggles for control and identity, and all of it conveyed in short scenes that weave together so that we never lose sight of the human toll in order for survival to offer a tiny degree of hope.

I have rarely given a book or show a "5", and almost did here. I definitely would have given it a 41/2 if it was an option. When I started watching "The Wire" I was a bit taken aback by how raw it is. But I think it in fact gives a frank presentation of the reality of the drug infused racial culture of Baltimore in the early part of this century. The first three seasons focused on the police and the drug dealers, with the exception of one season that concentrated on a longshoreman's union. During these prior seasons the viewer was made aware of the terrible environment where the African Americans lived, and the incredible efforts needed to escape such a place. Season 4 goes much deeper into this cultural deprivation that the young black men are faced with, and how it can overcome the best efforts of both the children and those who sincerely want to help them.  Season 4 traces four specific youngsters who are trying to be better that their surroundings, their peers, and, in most cases, their parents. It is a sad and gripping story that is presented in a compelling fashion. To me, this is the series at its very best-perhaps TV at its very best.

I just finished season 4 of The Wire.  The story arc and writing is even better than previous seasons.  We follow 4 friends in West Baltimore who's lives are each touched by the drug trade. Beginning with the waning  days of summer vacation, we progress through the school year with them.  Finally we have someone to care  about, we fear for them, hope for them, even cry for, as well as with them. The power of the street life threatens them daily, yet there is always an instance of concern and filial love to assist for at least one day.
We have a ranking police officer who finds a way to curb the violence and fear of the citizen of West Baltimore, only to be struck down by the blindness and heavy hand of outdated criminal and drug codes.  How many good men and women have faced this situation in real life.
Finally, there are the politicians, crafty and cunning, for whom do they work, themselves or the citizenry. A great show, The Wire.

This show is by far one of the best shows ever produced for television.  The acting was superb.  The plotlines and sub plotlines and the flow of those many parts into one great, sensible whole was exciting to watch.  I was one of those who watched all five seasons on my Amazon Prime, and the drama and story lines had me so caught up that I watched at least three a day (for a guy who watches only four hours a week, that is WAY more than usual).  So you can say I was really amazed by the great story telling.

Now, one may ask, why four stars then?  Well, it is because almost everyone on the show was an amoral, immoral, filthy mouthed, sexually perverted person.  Almost EVERYONE!  I mean,  couldn't there be at least one out of five people within the plot that was at least a decent guy who didn't throw out F bombs all the time or revel in porn mags?  Isn't there at least ONE out of ten who didn't drink to get drunk?  McNulty's new girlfriend, Beadie (and McNulty himself for Season Four) was somewhat decent.  But it seemed like David Simon was born and raised only with crossing the ethical line thugs or something.  Because they were all pretty vile people.

The 4th season is where The Wire kind of drops the ball.  Getting into the lives of teenagers lowers the tone, partly because of poor acting, partly because the kid they push to the front of the story (the Naymond Bryce character) is an insufferable little punk played by an actor with no discernible talent.

  Season 1 had some teenagers who could actually act, playing characters essential to the storyline.  Season 4 has a whole subcast of untalented actors whose characters don't even advance the storyline.  It looks like some bad wroters wrote in terrible characters and a bad casting director was hired to fill roles with miserably untalented kids that get in the way of the story.  The characters from earlier seasons who were already over the top as "larger than life" become a little less credible, as well.

  It's unforgivable, also, that the writers show the killers' nail gun as a nearly silent tool, when a powder actuated Hilti is as loud as any pistol.  Why this tool is written into the script as a character is a mystery.  The killers already had  battery powered nail gun that would be as quiet as they wanted us to believe the Hilti was.

  The story also veers off into the lives of the politicians, and those characters are even less interesting than the teenagers.  None of the actors playing the roles of politicians are good at the job of acting.  Still, the story keeps us hooked, and the characters who made us care about the city and the people manage to carry this season well enough to get fans through.

 The acting is terrible in some instances.  The actors who pay the following roles: Marla Daniels, Clay Davis, Kima Greggs and Naymond Bryce are every bit as awful as the characters they portray.  Casting these actors in anything is a mistake.  None of them would have been acceptable in anything other than one line walk on parts.

  One other problem with this series is that the subtitles, always poorly done, are even less accurate in season 4 than they were in the first three seasons.  In season 4, the subtitles seem to be written by people who haven't read the script and depend on their tin ears to fill in for the hearing impaired.  Slim Charles tell Bodie that "Nary a Barksdale is left" and the tin eared subtitle writers translate that into "Mayor Barksdale is left".  This kind of thing goes on in every episode.

  The 4th season is the weakest in terms of storyline and acting ability.  Suffer through it and things get a little better in the final season.

Season 4 is the best season of the best TV show there ever was. Obviously if you haven't seen this show for whatever reason you should start from season one and watch the whole lot. The you can get used to every other show comparing unfavorably to this one like everybody else.

Another excellent season of The Wire. This season takes a closer look at how the whole drug/crime scene starts in a person. More specifically, how young they are when they start living the street life. A very real take on how they act in school and interact with each other and their teachers. The storyline of Marlo is still moving along and his two cronies are very easy to hate. You learn a little more about one of them but in the end you're really only hoping for one result for the both of them. We also get a look into the struggles of the mayor and city council and the political games he must play to keep the city running.

If I had to find one thing I didn't like in this season it has to be the lack of Dominic West on the screen. Although it makes sense because his storyline came to a halt, I always enjoy seeing him on the screen as he tends to make every scene he is in better in some way.

Looking forward to season 5 and finishing one of the best series I have ever seen.

This season was a complete triumph of storytelling. We see the outcome of the politics of Season 3 come to fruition and get introduced into how education plays a role in the lives of Baltimore's citizens. Seeing how everything is interconnected and how the butterfly effect comes into place is so completely well done. We get introduced to new characters -- the very opening scene of the season with Snoop buying a new nail gun is fantastic; and say goodbye to others that had been around since day one.

It's a terrific roller coaster of a season that you cannot miss if you're a fan of the series.

This is one of the most powerful seasons of the wire. It showcases the social,  economic,  political issues that low income communities face as well as the poor educational system,  foster care and drug/alcohol / and violence that shape the lives of the less fortunate.  This season focused on the children which is gut wrenching.  Excellent writing and depiction of the real issues occurring in our society.
Great Series

Excellent presentation of problems that plague many cities.  The Wire doesn't, and never tries or claims,to portray Baltimore City as a whole.  For anyone looking for solutions to these problems, this series shows those issues clearly and they must be understood before effective solutions can be found.

Season 4 of The Wire centers on the election and subsequent win to the mayor's office by Tommy Carcetti and Marlo Stanfield, the new player on the block.

With a huge reduction in force for the Major Crimes Unit, everybody has bailed out with the exception of two lonely detectives, Herc - having just made Sgt after working two months in the mayor's office under Royce, and Dozerman who have been instructed by their new Major, Marimow, to "rip and run".  No long term work, just street rips.

With political jockeying going up the chain to the mayor's office, everything looks to be shaken up.  However, Marlo remains a problem.  Nobody moves up and expands without dropping bodies and the bodies aren't being found.  Until... Randy Wagstaff, well played by Maestro Harrell, spills the beans to the vice principal of his school.

It is hard watching these "children".  Knowing the inner city world as I once did, it hurts to see innocence stripped away at such a young age.  Kids who should be enjoying comic books, riding bikes and generally goofing around are either carrying the weight of their family or on the street slinging.

I love the show and have enjoyed each season bringing us a different focus in the life of the city. The main focus in season four is the schools. There is a specific focus on a group of middle schoolers as Prez begins his career as a teacher, and Bunny works with some sociologists on a research project that seems to really help some of the corner kids. We also see how testing doesn't really serve that population very well, and yet the teachers and the school admin are under enormous pressure to conform. And the newly elected mayor's good intentions come into conflict with his political ambitions, and the schools suffer, as do our friends in Major Crimes.
The focus on this kids was heartbreaking. I kept thinking that one of those boys could have been Freddie Gray.

While "The Wire" is often considered to be among the best shows of an era along with Breaking Bad, Game of Thrones, and the Sopranos, season 4 is something of an aberration.

An aberration because even when compared to other shows that are often heralded as "great", the case can be made that The Wire: Season 4 leaves the competition behind.  Quite simply, this is one of the best seasons of television ever produced in history.  And while one might typically caution against over-hyping so as not to set a degree of expectation for the uninitiated that can never be met, it seems unlikely that the typical rules apply here.

Every detail of this season sparkles.  Even with principle character Det. Jimmy McNulty taking a noticeable back seat to the rest of the cast, the characters and story lines that come to the forefront are so engaging, so compelling, that the viewer feels a sense of urgency for resolution each time the show cuts away to a different story line, only to have that feeling immediately return as they invariably get sucked into the next plot point.

The adolescent characters are beautifully written, and portrayed with remarkable nuance by a young cast.  David Simon, Ed Burns and the rest of the writing staff are careful to prevent any of them from becoming one-note, or falling into stereotypes.  As per the show's M.O., viewers will find themselves growing attached in different ways to each of the new characters, while familiar faces from seasons past continue to evolve and show us new sides to their personalities.

The Wire Season 4 is to television what A Christmas Carol is to literature.  It is often profound, sometimes shocking, and will leave you questioning our nation's inextricable marriage of politics, the criminal justice system, and our misguided public education curriculum.

Highest possible recommendation.

Like the previous seasons, the show takes a few episodes to set up the new characters, plots and relationships. This show never comes out swinging, but rather carefully crafts the trajectory of new themes while continuing previous threads established in previous episodes.

Season 4 strikes at the heart of the problems of gang life in that it establishes the how when and where it begins with young black youth. It also shows how political and financial systems continue to feed the problems of inner city poverty  as well as benefitting  from the problems of inner city gangs and drug culture...

  But in season 4 there is also a strong thread of hope; A newly elected mayor who genuinely wants to go good, a retired police commander who decides to work with youth, an ex-cop turned teacher, and a former gang soldier/ex/felon among others are out to make a difference... And at the halfway mark of season 4 things are looking up...

Like the previous seasons of wired, this series is some of the best written, filmed, acted and directed television there is.

The gritty realism of the show continues to ring very true to me during season 4: I grew up on the south side of Cgucsgo on the fringes of minority youth crime and drugs. There are few, if any, "Hollywood endings" in this series.

  And though sometimes that's hard to swallow, I feel it's important that the show doesn't seem to let its viewers off of the emotional hook. Life is very, very hard at the bottom of our society's ladder simply because there are few if any easy choices for inner city youth surrounded mostly by hopelessness. And it's not that their lives are hard, but it's pointlessly un-necessarily hard. This show dramatizes that with no excuses and apparently without making any moral judgements about their plight.

One of the top ten television series of all time.  It chronicles the life of many poor inner city black Americans better than any TV series or Movie that has ever been made.  It is very intelligently written and directed with believable characters.  The social comments it makes on politics, the media and law enforcement are spot on.  This series shows the bad old days of police brutality that has been so much in the news lately.  It also demonstrates how futile the war on drugs was.  It has a huge ensemble cast (with many locals from Baltimore) with remarkable acting performances.  One of the more disturbing commentaries featured on the show was how self serving politicians are.

Probably the most disappointing of all seasons so far.  West's performance as McNulty and Elba's Stringer Bell are absent and most will miss them.  Also largely gone is the relationship between Mcnulty and Bunk which drives the humor of the first seasons.  The show is no longer driven by Mcnulty and the show's entertainment value drops pretty severely.  The writing is still supreme and the performances are brilliant but somehow the tension of chasing Stringer Bell made the show compelling and losing that plot line diminished my passion for the season.  Following the mayor of Baltimore and his challenger just made for less appealing story despite the excellent script and superb acting.

I just can't bring myself to rate this series or this season as the "epic" program that others described it to be. Good entertainment? Sure. Do I care about many of the characters? Yes. But as I continue with the series I keep asking myself what the big deal is. I have felt much more interested in many other programs (like BBC's Broadchurch, Season 1 for example). I found that the complexity of the characters dropped dramatically after Season 1 - and for the most part, "good guys and bad guys" roles fell back into the usual, predictable categories. Season 2 was useless, Season 3 revived some interest, and this, Season 4, had more powerful moments than the previous two, but still didn't seem to move the series forward in any particularly interesting or surprising ways. I've grown indifferent to the show and didn't want to bother with Season 5, but they left enough untied that I might go ahead for the sake of closure. I've definitely lost the drive to watch like I had at the beginning.

This is a hard hitting cops & drug dealers drama, but it's way beyond anything I've ever seen.  These scripts take one inside the Baltimore police with its power struggles, politics, incompetence, and yes heroic efforts to save a few souls along the way on a day to day job that often is incredibly boring not to mention full of bureaucratic bulls***.  And this is played out against the inner city drug gang with its own competition and corruption and deal making not to mention the toll taken on kids who seldom find a way out of this culture to a better life.  The acting is superb within stories that constantly twist, turn and bring surprises.  Many a night I turn off the TV saying, "Jesus, was that ever dark," and still I go back to this deeply moving, complex and challenging series.  I've got one more year of this show to look forward to, and wish it would never end.
Great intelligent show
Good show, I will watch it again one day.

Slow-moving, but remains fairly interesting. There are episodes, during which, I started thinking "Is this episode actually relevant?" For the most part, it's still worth watching if you've made it this far. If season three was boring for you, then this one may not be worth your time. Marlo is not a formidable point of conflict but the city itself becomes the main focus, and that is very interestingI just think they could have spent more time actually focusing on that to make it a little more evident. Michael K. Williams is a phenomenal actorOmar Little is the most interesting character in this series, IMHOHe was great in Boardwalk Empire as well... I can't wait to see what he does next!

As someone who has worked with "inner-city" kids (a title I don't particularly care for) I will say that they got the attitudes pretty spot ona little over the topbut it's a drama, y'all! What they over-simplified a little is being able to reach those children; it's not impossible, but it's very difficult. I do appreciate the way teachers are portrayed: not too loving, but tough-loving, and very serious about jumping through the bureaucratic hoops to serve their students well. I no longer work with kidshonestly, I couldn't handle it. Hug a teacher, folksthey deserve it! Actually, to Hell with a hug! Go volunteer, it's important! Especially if you are blessed with thick skin AND a heart...

Well not sure what to say at this point. At season 4 everyone probably knows that this is an amazing show. I'll mention a few of the major plot points which are a bit different like in seasons past. First you see the race for mayor and then the political challenges after the election. The corner kids as they are called are a main focus as well with their lives on the streets and in the classroom. Also Marlo is the main guy on the streets right now so you get to see about his crew and the police after him as well.

My only complaint is that McNulty is hardly in this season. Obviously a main character in past seasons and someone I like allot. The season ends with what looks like him being set up to be in the main action again though. Although this is a bit of a criticism I have on the show, its still amazing as always. I really enjoyed the race for mayor and even more light on the political scene. This show really opens your eyes on how things really are in many aspects out there. Do yourself a favor and keep watching the Wire.

Took me all this time to finally watch this show after years of people telling me to do so, and I regret not watching it sooner.  The Wire is maybe the finest written and produced television drama I've ever seen. This is as realistic a crime drama as you are going to get, and, sadly, the realism is all too true for the streets of West Baltimore still.  The Wire's inside look at the interconnectivity between the drug gangs, the police, the politicians, and the local media is almost like being there 24/7.  If you haven't watched this brilliant show yet don't make the same mistake I made.  Ya feel me?

A continuation of great character development and raw insights into a big city police department bureaucracy, inner city drug gang, and local newspaper teetering on the verge of financial collapse. Bub's redemption was awesome and helped counterbalance the staged serial killer silliness. But I hope a season 6 appears some day!

Brilliant rendition of the failure of post industrial America, particularly in the education system. Fine acting all around from the cast. This season was an allusion to the truth about how our country has no longer continued to reach out to the lower class of the ladder to help them out of their blight. What is worse is that the line between good and bad has become severely blurred in politics and and law enforcement. The name of the game is now called getting over. The victims of this tragedy have seemingly given up on shooting for the "ideal American Dream".

Another excellent season from one of the best shows on television. This season we are introduced to group of middle school aged students, some of who work the corners in Baltimore's inner city, some who are trying to find a way out of the drug scene. The ensemble work by this group of young actors is outstanding. They are Jermaine Crawford, Maestro Harrell, Julito McCullum and Tristan Wilds. Also deserving special mention are two who were on the law and order side in previous seasons: Jim True-Frost, as a detective turned math teacher and Robert Wisdom as a former Major turned counselor/mentor working with the most incorrigible students. This season had a lot of heart and also broke some hearts as events seemed to have a way of ensnaring these young men. Once you start this season you'll want to watch it through to the end.

Great season with great characters. Although I did miss some of the drug underworld stuff, its replaced with a very realistic look into how the lives children are affected by poverty. Its probably the most depressing season but it also has the most potential to affect viewers. All too many times, children in these circumstances are looked upon as a statistic and honestly most of America has no idea how disconnected this type of environment is from the "American Dream." This is the type of piece I would consider being required for some type of humanities class. You can't see this and then make throw-a-way statements about impoverished people somehow just working hard enough to get out of the cycle. I'm only knocking it down a star because I did miss some of the organized crime stuff.

I can't give it 5 stars. The Wire is a very original series with great characters and good actors. However, it's difficult for me to stay with it with so much profanity. I've never had to listen to this kind of language on the job or anywhere else I am on a regular basis. The professionals with whom I work and my circle of friends and family would never accept this kind of crude, filthy language. Most consider it uneducated and very low class, which I suppose is representative of the poor and ghetto areas of a city, but doesn't seem realistic in an office setting. The nudity and sex are mostly unnecessary, but it is HBO after all.

I've stuck with it because I want to see how it ends. The irony with which I am most impressed is that The Wire seems to be prophetic of the current Baltimore.

Season 4 continues to be gripping though we are not finished yet, almost.  We are particularly interested now (though we started the series before) given what is going on in Baltimore these days.  I read a criticism in a magazine of the series recently and felt it was unfounded.
It is amazing to me that the writer/producer were able to get so much reality into such a complicated social system that exists in the inner cities of America.
My only complaint is that I continue to have trouble understanding what everyone is saying, some more than others, and we rely on closed captions to help us out. Also I think some of the goody goody stuff that appears in this Season is a bit too goody goody, though it is true some kids can be turned around. but in these scenes even the delivery of lines seems off.
  But nevertheless I can't wait each night to see what happening to the characters whom I've come to know.

One of the biggest complaints about The Wire presented in an HD format is that the original look and feel of the show is lost due to image cropping at the top and bottom of the screen to make the originally square image fit on a widescreen TV.

I'm a stickler for that sort of thing. And I watched The Wire on HBO when it came out in it's original format. And I didn't even notice the difference. The show transforms to a 16:9 ratio very well without impacting the artistic quality of the series.

So don't hesitate to watch The Wire presented on Amazon in a widescreen format. The quality is great and you'll enjoy the show just as much (or more) than you did the first time you watched it.

I was immediately taken in by season 4 because it hit close to home...the school system. It tells the truth.  Yes, I'm a teacher, but anybody connected with schools, including parents, Boards, administrators, and anybody who ever went to school, should care about season four.  The Wire shows the futility of one school system, the one down in the hole, but it transfers to so many of them above ground.  Prez, who didn't have much going for him in his old job as a cop, becomes a teacher.  I''m not reiterating here that "Those who CAN do, and those who can't, teach," but in a tough, undisciplined environment, you'd think an ex-cop would excel.  Not so.  Prez stood there while one student sliced the face of another.  An issue which puzzled him, as well as the other teachers, was that their whole job was just teaching to the test.  What's new?  One teacher expressed that the only thing these kids needed to learn was how to survive.  There's often one student you care about because they show promise.  Dukie was one of these.  He could do computers, but it didn't work.  The environment he came from was stronger than the hope Prez had for the boy.  My favorite character, Bubbles, who survived by informing the police about what went on in the drug culture he lived in, tried to keep Sharrod, his young protege in school.  It didn't work. Bubbles accidentally killed him while trying to off another person who was constantly abusing him.  Too sad.
We do see that one of the four new young boys entering season 4 tries to save his little brother despite a tragic home life by keeping him in school.  He can't do it because he gets too involved in the violence, and must sadly send him to a relative (a new environment) to live.  But we see the little one crying as he leaves the car, and we can only hope that the loss of his big brother won't destroy him.  It's reality beautifully portrayed.

In season four we still have the police following the drugs.  Marlo represents the worst of the drug kingpins you find in a place like this.  He's smart, ambitions but ill-advised, thinking he could run with the Greeks and their international business. He actually kills lots of people but hides them in vacant buildings so there aren't any bodies.  Stringer used to be tops, being a legitimate businessman, but he worked both sides of the street, which will always catch up with you.  And Avon Barksdale, the main one the police have been chasing, is in jail.

In season 4, the main theme, which started in season 3, was politics. It is so representative "down in the hole", as it is above ground.  In three, when politicians were adamant about keeping the numbers below 300 by pushing the druggies off the corners and into safe zones called Hamsterdam, I laughed. That was hilarious. And up-and-coming politician, Carcetti, reminds me of all of the young presidential hopefuls today. You think he's a good guy, but you don't really know.  He keeps changing.  Just because McNulty, main cop, detective, etc. in the show, gets interested in the homeless, Carcetti does...or seems to.  Everybody always wants to tackle the "Homeless" problem.
The show tells it like it is.

This series is fantastic. It covers the plight of the inner city residents, politicians & bureaucrats, police, jobless, criminal element, poverty stricken and the lost. The Wire allows us a fly on the wall (seemingly accurate) view of a society lost in a downward spiral, it draws us in and shows that a really bad guy can have a good side to him. It is sad, poignant, thought provoking and enjoyable entertainment. It should encourage us all to be compassionate, thinking and seeking ways to improve the lot of people caught up in this horrible environment where it seems nothing changes.

Saw all 5 seasons and found it a very gripping show with excellent characterisations and acting.  Language is VERY crude, sometimes unnecessarily so, and the Afro American dialogue is sometimes very difficult to understand
It is an eye opener as to the extent of corruption in all walks of life and in the life in the city of Baltimore.

Story is a bit complicated and it is advised to read an introduction and get an idea of the storyline and the main  characters.  In particular getting to know the names and roles of the Afro American cast.  As the show develops the story lines and characters become very grappling and entertaining.

I found it a more gripping and enjoyable show than Breaking Bad.

I'm always surprised, if not shocked, when a likeable character, from either side of the tracks, gets eliminated. Its a good series, that I think is worth investing a little time to explore. This is a very well developed series with the rare sense to not drag the story beyond its attention-holding limits. In S.4, the leitmotive established in S.1 becomes a device that explains and expands the story of the fast deteriorating state of "education" in the USA, or the systemic corruption of the social foundations gradually replaced with clay feet.

Even the most dense viewer watching S.4 has to grasp the obvious hint writ large: the pathocrats' experiment in successfully trashing the silent and fearful 99.9% by preying on their stupidity, greed, racism and pseudo religiosity, whatever their skin color, has succeeded. Or to paraphrase pastor Niemoeller's words:
  While they trashed the future of the Black community,
  The Whites said nothing, because they lived far from the the inner city ghettoes.
  While they derided the Gays' desire for a full family and social life,
  The pseudo-religious fanatics said nothing, because they believed their corrupt pastors.
  When they attacked women who prefer an abortion to bringing an unwanted and unloved life into being,
  The bigots said nothing, because their stupidity prevented them from seeing themselves as their puppet masters' useful idiots.
  When the carpet is finally pulled from under the immoral majority,
  There will be no one left to speak for them.

The crashing of the once mighty empire is in free fall and about to pass the point of no return; the lesson of the entire series.
Kudos to everyone who made this series a most deeply meaningful experience.

This season made me re-evaluate every assumption I've ever made about the role drugs and poverty plays in the cycle of violence and hopelessness that inner-city residents are forced to contend with on a day-to-day basis.  It explores the enormous disconnect between white America and black America and was summarized amazingly well by the principal of the middle school around which the action revolves:  "You can't save all of them."

This should be required viewing by educators and law makers everywhere.  The season was exceptionally well-written and the story line will keep your attention from episode one through the end.  This is intelligent television and begs the viewers to make up their own minds over complex issues; you don't feel so much guided along to draw conclusions as you feel forced through a gauntlet of one misfortune after the next, with only occasional glimmers of hope to prevent you from succumbing to despair.

Season Four of The Wire is among the greatest seasons of any television series in the last twenty years.  Nearly ten years after filming ended, this show remains frighteningly relevant.

Many of the characters return, including Omar and Bubbles. One of the best seasons of this show!

Season 4 does not disappoint.  The writers for The Wire manage to interweave characters and plot lines from previous seasons with a new core storyline about a group of young friends trying to make it on the mean streets of inner city Baltimore.  You see the consequences of self-absorbed political horse trading behind the scenes, affecting everything from police investigations to school funding and programs.  The undercurrent of violence and heartbreak is never far from view, playing out in cold brutality but all baked inside "the game", the hard, unforgiving world of the drug dealers, their suppliers and their tormentors, yes Omar is back with a vengeance.  You see well intentioned characters trying to change the course of events, each in their own way, some trying to save some small personal semblance of morality, others trying to do for friends what they couldn't for themselves.  You see the black hole pull of the drug world, sucking people in as hapless users, beckoning to the still innocent to join in and earn some hard to come by cash.  There is hope here but it's thwarted so often and so tragically at times.  One thing this season does as all others, it whets your appetite for Season 5.  Ultimately, this is where The Wire's success resides, in the way it makes you root for characters or stifle the urge to smile at their demise.  Another moving and powerful effort with terrific performances, brilliant camera work, directing and writing.  Enjoy...

Gives a panoramic view of the Petry dish that is Baltimore.  The kids, pushers, gangsters, cops, politicians, lawyers, addicts, they are all part of the scope.  This is a rough and tumble show with an abundance of gratuitous violence, foul language, and sex.  Yet it seems to be a realistic rendition of life in the ghetto.  Takes a whille to get into it but will grab you.  Very good.

Season 4 takes awhile to get going. The unit is disbanded by the politics of the police department and the city. The main star of the show, takes a back seat. That would be the character of McNulty. I have read that the actor who plays him had requested a lesser role to spend more time with his family in Europe, so that explains that situation. There are still many great characters in this season. The bad guy you like to root for is Omar, who is a modern day Robin Hood. And of course Bubbles, who starts taking a regular beating from a street thug. He does ask for help from the Herc, who promises him help. Bubbles doesn't get any and plays a great prank on Herc, then Bubbles seems to know he has to take matters into his own hands.

Pres has given up police work and ends up becoming a teacher in a rough middle school. But his life still intertwines with his fellow officers.

The Major Crime squad starts to get back into action after the new Mayor takes the reins and tries to eliminate some of the politics of the BPD.

Although this series seems to take a different path from the previous 3 seasons, it's still a great show and I enjoy it tremendously.

The Wire is a fantastic show.  I served in Afghanistan as an instructor/adviser with the national counterinsurgency center from 2011-2012.  I wish I would have seen it and had it available as an instructional reference.  The corollaries between the description of the environment in this show and the reality of Afghanistan are stunning.  The only differences are the scale of the problem in Afghanistan: and that the "drug cartel" in the real operational environment is in open conflict with government to control territory.

Remember Wallace from the 1st season, one of the young corner kids who took care of a group of younger siblings, saw them off to school, making sure they had something to eat? He was one of my absolute favorite characters, who sickened by the violence took off for a while but came back because the projects -the low and high risers- was all he knew. Now imagine a whole group of Wallaces having to play the hands they've been dealt with, each doing so in his own particular way. They're not a compilation of cliches, but are living, breathing human beings trying to navigate a dangerous world as they find their own paths in life. It's heart-breaking and also also quite inspiring.

I think that one of the reasons this season is so strong is because we came to care for those four children. We saw them struggle in the face of their abandonment, first by their parents and then by the schools. We rooted for them. When we saw three of them becoming men, we sensed the possibility that no one would ever root for them again. We saw how the children we cared for could be cast off as adults  (Is this where David Simon implicates us, the viewers?)  Namond was the lucky one. He was taken in by Colvin and he was given the opportunity to thrive, which only made us ponder the many "what if"s that eluded the others.

The Wire deals with politics, police and poverty in Baltimore. The title of the series comes from season one, and law enforcement's attempt to quell drug sales and the violence that always accompanies it using wire taps.
But this show, one of  HBO's finest,  goes far beyond that. Each season of The Wire focused on one area in the war on drugs and its casualties.
 Season 4 deals with education, and while it takes place in Baltimore, it surely could be any mid-sized city...And quite a few small towns as well.  The Wire shows young, YOUNG people...some good, some bad, some on the fence, but ALL trapped in a cycle of poverty, drugs and the political processes that continue to fail them.
The acting is incredible. The writing, impeccable. The stories, undeniably moving.  The Wire is gritty, violent,  and unabashedly realistic. The language is often coarse,  the action unmistakably adult. This drama holds nothing back, and surely is not for everyone. But if you appreciate hard-hitting urban drama, police procedure, or political maneuvers, please give The Wire a chance.
Great show

Sharpens how difficult it is for any elected reform candidate to change anything in a city totally in the grip of declining revenues, corruption and careerism.  Watching David Simon's and Ed Burns's brilliant screen plays, and the taut acting and directing, makes one wonder how it is that previously troubled cities are now the center of political and civic progress, while state and federal government continues to look more like these depictions of Baltimore ten years ago. After four seasons, this is still an amazing show.  This may be the best season yet, as we move into the school system, and see the different ways that kids on the streets can be "educated," whether it's in the schools or on the streets. We grew very attached to several of the kids, and were devastated as their stories unfolded to the finale.  This was one of the best shows on T.V. ever.  Our only criticism is that every season (and we're now starting our fifth), the ending is depressing.  This season, another one of the major characters is killed off.  While there's frequently hope on an individual basis and while individuals, including the teachers, police and government officials, strive to make the system work and make their communities better, there's never an uplifting end to any season, even though there's always an expectation people will keep trying.  We love the realism of the show, but it's the same story arc, even though each storyline is new and incredibly insightful. It often feels like a Shakespearean tragedy, where things can go either way, but where many of our favorite characters are star-crossed and even as they strive to do the right thing, particularly the street kids, they are doomed.  I feel I've learned a lot about how local government, the public schools, crime and corruption all work in tandem.  It's been an education.  I only wish, just once, the season could have ended on a generally uplifting note.

The wire series from HBO and David Simon is an example of art copying life.  After working for three years on a federal drug squad in Baltimore circa 1980s my drug enforcement days come rushing back to me when I watch the Wire.  Sometimes the names have been changed to protect the guilty.  Sometimes Simon uses real names but changes the character's role.  I think the early seasons are the best.  By season five it goes over top.

One of the best seasons of one of the best shows ever made. The Wire season 4 takes an entirely new look at Baltimore through the stories of a few of the teenagers living there. Their stories overlap with the bigger picture of the crime and how the city has failed them as a whole. Highly recommend the entire series, especially this season. It is heartbreaking at times.

This is one of the rare shows you won't mind watching more than once. The characters are so well-rounded there'll be times when you're hoping the bad guy wins and the good guy fails. It doesn't portray criminals as just monsters terrorizing neighborhoods, but as men and women who have aspirations and fears just like you and I.

The plot thickens and the cops take more chances to apprehend the bad guys in the forth season of the Wire.  There is more intrigue and action in this season with many unexpected plot twists that keep you guessing who will emerge from this alive and with their careers intact.  The story takes some strange turns in the last episode but you have to see each installment to understand how they all ended up where they do...and where this will take the next season of the Wire!

The Wire is so realistic and natural that it's easy to forget that the actors are acting, and I don't think I gave them enough credit in seasons 1-3. As others have mentioned, it was a risky move to put four middle school-aged kids at the forefront of this season. But it worked. I was truly riveted by the acting in this season. Without the heartfelt, honest performances of young actors Maestro Harrell, Jermaine Crawford, Julito McCullum and Tristan Wilds, season 4 could have turned out far differently. Robert Wisdom's Bunny Colvin is a character so full of honor and humility that I get choked up just thinking of his time on screen. (Without giving anything away, his scene with Wee-Bey is a thing of beauty.) Andre Royo is at the top of his game as Bubbles tragically hits rock bottom. Gbenga Akinnagbe is quietly terrifying as Chris Partlow, and Clarke Peters and Wendell Pierce never, ever disappoint. There is so much I could rave about, but there isn't much to say that hasn't already been said. Season 4 of The Wire is simply television at its best. It's smart, funny, gritty, thought-provoking, and, in a way that previous seasons had not been, utterly heartbreaking.

If you have yet to discover this amazing series, wire yourself in immediately!!!  The first season was honestly a little slow, and I wondered what everyone had been raving about.  Stick with it and you will be rewarded with brilliantly written stories peopled with characters from every walk of life.  Andre Royo is a revelation as "Bubbles" the drug addict struggling to create his own "shopping cart empire", as is Idris Elba playing a powerful drug king pin and doing a great American accent - yes, ladies he's actually from England!  Every character is fascinating in their foibles and their humanity.  The picture painted of these particular areas of Baltimore is horrendous and was a revelation for this British expat - actually it bears a strong resemblance to areas of Liverpool, England (my hometown) or the Watts/Compton areas of L.A. - but no matter where the location, the inhabitants are compelling!  Not for the faint hearted, this gritty drama blows other dvd series out of the water.

Since I do not subscribe to HBO, I was not familiar with The Wire prior to buying the first season based purely on the likeness of Dominic West on the box cover.  I had seen Mr. West in the BBC production of The Hour and became an admirer at that time both of him and the show.
I took the set of the first season home, settled down and watched the first episode, then the second, the third and soon I had devoured all five.  Fascinated with the story lines as well as the acting, I soon availed myself of the remaining seasons.  I finished the last of season five late last night. It is quite simply the best show of its kind on television.
A major appeal is that while writers David Simon, Ed Burns et al set the story in Baltimore, the plots could have been ripped from our local papers.  Deadly home invasions, drug busts, police chiefs resigning under pressure, newspapers hanging on by a thread, disillusion with bureaucratic bunglers and so on and so on.
In fact, when I pass the sets on to my friends and relatives, I include pertinent news clippings from our daily papers.  Having taught in the local public schools, I can attest to the authenticity of Prezbos experience.
Just as the writing is superb with literary references juxtaposed with gritty street language, so is the acting.  Literally dozens of performances could be praised were there space enough and time, but the aforementioned West along with Idris Elba as Stringer Bell and Andre Royo as Bubbles, especially Bubbles, were outstanding.
What lifts The Wire above its competition is the complexity of the characters.  A couple seems purely evil while the others are purely human.  That is they have layers of moralitysometimes admirable, oftentimes not so much.  The pressure they endure of trying to do their jobs, to survive, to perhaps prevail only to be frustrated  allows the viewer to empathize with their situations even while deploring their clay feet.
Each season tackles a different aspect of the situations they face: the police, the schools, the newspaper, the politics and shows how they are intertwined and how the individuals are caught in the web.
Great, great production and Im grateful that its available on CD as its possible to get more out of the experience by having it all available at once instead of waiting for weeks.  Thanks Mr. Simon and thanks Amazon.
