This is the best show on television that is not winning awards but giving in sight to a world that never gets any real viewing. I love the show in general but this season show how they become drug dealer or don't.

"The Wire" is simply the best TV show ever. Nearly anything Rod Serling scripted for television was gold, but records are made to be broken and new champs take their place among the pantheon of excellence. David Simon's epic series "The Wire" has gone where no series has dared tread. The writing is bold, provocative and absolutely necessary. I will be sadden on Mar. 30, 2008 when the series finally concludes, but I am greatful for having had the opportunity to enjoy this great work of art since its debut. Bravo to all who labored on this fantastic show. The fact that the Television Academy of Arts and Sciences hasn't recognized this show for its acting, writing, direction and cinematography only illustrates the vapid wasteland of programing that Hollywood continues to produce and reward. For those who say there aren't enough African Americans represented on television, you folks have been watching the wrong show. "The Wire" has the best ensemble of actors of any color ever assembled. Storytelling like this comes once in a lifetime.

If you have enjoyed previous seasons of The Wire, then I don't think you'll be disappointed with this one. Branching out into a study of the schools system alongside the more usual police and drug culture storylines, this remains a powerful and fascinating series.

The finest programme on television.

The best show on TV continues to impress in season four as the writers choose to focus on public education in the City of Baltimore.  The realest show out there, if you're not watching it you're doing yourself a disservice.  I was skeptical that the show would not fall off a bit but to my surprise this was the best season yet!

The fourth season of the Wire is another great one in this series.  With the focus on the schools and the group of four friends trying to survie in the Baltimore projects - it is more similar to season two than the first and third in feel.  The rise of Marlo is a nice added element and the end of the season leaves you wanting more.

This is by far one of the best television programs that I have ever seen.  The violence and brutality are very realistic and its great because they aren't afraid to kill off a good character.

A piece of advice: Don't start out with the fourth season. You owe it to yourself to watch it from the beginning.

I tend to sit through most of each episode with my jaw dropped in amazement - I can't believe how great this show is.  I don't watch much television, but this is unlike anything else I've ever seen.  It combines fantastic entertainment with stark reality - I've learned so much from this series.  I wish it would go on for another five years...

It's very rare that a show gets better each season but the Wire is doing just that. After a decade or so of some of the worst tv both here in Oz, the US or the UK things seem to be really picking up. HBO in particular has  produced some of the finest work in the Sopranos, Deadwood and now the Wire. I'm half way through this fourth season and already it seems like it will be the best yet. It's a pity the fifth is to be the last but it is better for this show to end on a high than stick around too long like a lot of so called popular shows do. Case in point "That 70's show". Started out brilliant but is now almost embarrassingly predictable.

There's no point in reading this review- or watching this season of The Wire- without having started at the beginning.  So - to address those who have come this far:  the pace is quite gentle at first, and you may miss some of the key characters from previous seasons, though some of them return- some in unexpected and rather delightful ways.  This season, though, is all about the kids- and there's a lot of time spent at school and in Cutty's boxing gym.  Seriously, all the adult characters apart from Carcetti and Mayor Royce are pretty much bit-part players, though with Carcetti's lapse into cynicism amid fears of losing an election, it somehow seems that Bunny Coleman remains the moral compass of the piece, even though he's no longer a police.  So- it's about the kids- will they stand a chance of a decent life or will the corners claim them?  The young actors are entertaining and gripping in their own way and you already have some ideas as to which characters will end up good and those whose lives will be a Baltimore dead end.
Talking of bit-players, Omar is still with us and is as brilliantly alienated an outsider anti-hero as has even been played in mainstream  TV drama.
Overall, The Wire remains of an impossibly high standard and sets a bar of sorts for all forms of serious art or culture- it's ambitions are huge and it nails every single one of them.

This latest season was even more captivating than the last!  I suggest you buy all of the previous seasons... It's the best show I've followed in years!  I can't wait until season 5 starts this month!

In this review, I assume you're already familiar with The Wire and are considering whether to continue into the 4th season.  If you're not already familiar with the show, buy (or rent) Season 1 - it's worth it, in fact it's one of the best shows on TV.  The rest of this review focuses on Season 4, and I'll do my best to avoid spoilers.

Season 4 of the wire takes some pretty dramatic turns from the previous 3 seasons, the most notable being the fact that the Barksdale gang is no more.  Bodie and Slim are still around, and even Wee-Bey makes some appearances this season, albeit from prison, but the Barksdale organization has been supplanted by Marlo.

The most interesting aspect of Season 4 is that, similar to how Season 2 focused on the dockworkers, Season 4 takes a very close look at the Baltimore school system (mainly via the eyes of Prez, who is now a teacher).  I know, the subject matter sounds boring but it's actually very well executed, with the focus on a group of young kids (Randy, Dukie, Namond, and Chris) and the pressures they face to get into "the game" at a very young age (younger than Bodie or even Wallace in season 1).  In this look into the school system, the social commentary aspect of the series is felt even more than in prior seasons, but it doesn't detract from the drama, if anything it enhances it.

Like the previous three seasons, the characters are excellent.  McNulty's role has been diminished significantly (he's a minor character in season 4, hopefully he'll play a bigger role in season 5), but he's been replaced by some new characters (the aforementioned kids) as well as some existing characters taking on greater roles (Carcetti is now a major character as he runs for mayor against incumbent Royce ... the election is a major facet of the plot this season).  Thankfully, Omar is still around and up to his old habits, and the confrontation between he and Marlo is excellent, but I won't spoil that.

The Bonus Features segment of this set included on disc 4 includes two very interesting mini-documentaries (about a half hour each) entitled "The Game is Real" and "It's All Connected".  I rarely bother with all the bonus features a lot of DVDs include, but these are worth watching.  I didn't know that the co-creators of The Wire are an ex detective, and an ex journalist (both worked in Baltimore of course), and, not surprisingly, a large amount of the material in The Wire is adapted from real world events.  Also not surprisingly, a large percentage of the men and women who work on the show are not career hollywood/TV types.  The documentaries provide a pretty interesting look at how the creators approach the show and how it has drawn inspiration from real world Baltimore.  Definately check these documentaries out if you buy the DVD set!

In summary, if you've already seen the first three seasons and are considering whether to continue The Wire, the answer is a resounding "yes".  In addition, the season ends by setting up for a potentially spectacular Season 5, which I'm really looking forward to.  I've heard that Season 5 will be the last season of The Wire, and while I'll miss it that's ok with me - I'd rather see a great series have a great ending, rather than spiral into a Soprano's style dive in its twilight years.
This is an awesome show. Highly recommended for real reality show. Shows the seeder side of the city of Baltimore. True that!

Without question THE WIRE is evidence of the finest work on television.  The fourth season includes Public Education as a topic, and it is dealt with in the same well-written, well-acted, superbly directed manner as the other topics THE WIRE has taken on - Politics, Police, Organized Crime, The War On Drugs, etc.

The Wire is the most realistic adaptation of the inner city I have ever witnessed.  If you live in a city like Oakland, Richmond, East LA, St. Louis, Detroit, etc. you live in a city like Baltimore.  You read of the killings everyday in the newspaper or hear of the shootings on the TV and radio and you wonder why?  The Wire gives a very clear reason on why. The best written story and acting I've seen on TV in years.  Not sure why it doesn't win all of the awards. I guess Hollywood cannot relate to what is real around them.  It gets my award now and for years to come.  I grew up in Richmond, CA and saw the progression of the drug trade and witnessed what it did to people. The Wire is life every day in the inner city.

The Wire is the best series out there. Season 4 is excellent- alot 'cleaner' than season 1- although we love season 1 also. We're very sad to learn that season 5 will be the final season. But you have to respect the writers for wanting to maintain integrity and not turn it into another night time soap opera.

The Wire is the best how on TV, but because it is too brutally real for many viewers, it has never achieved the popularity of the Sopranos or other HBO programs.  However, many people are getting into the show through the DVDs, just like I did.  Now I have HBO and I can't wait for the Season 5 premiere on January 6th.

Not much else to say about this show that hasn't already been said...offers a genuine, well thought-out, and eye-opening interpretation of all the facets of urban life and the politics that go with it...The Wire is especially authentic when juxtaposed with the absurdness of reality television...it should be noted that this season is only one component to the vehicle that is The Wire...the full flavor of this captivating drama can only be fully enjoyed when the viewer is privy to the attitudes and nuiances of the brilliantly constructed characters that David Simon has created and developed over the previous three seasons...

The Wire continues to put out the highest quality show on television.  Season four introduces the most endearing characters to date - four middle schoolers teatering on the brink, about to fall through the cracks.  This series is riveting, heart breaking, and simply too good to miss.

This is worth the hundred bucks they charge at the store. But to get it for $40 EARLIER than the store release . . . RIDIC. I feel sorry for anyone that hasn't been up on a wire over the Barksdale organization, the Greeks or Marlo Stanfield.
Great series.  It gives an unprecedented genuine look at our society and who plays a part in our community's problems.  Raw, gritty and straight to the point!

There isn't much I can say about the show because if you follow it, it's like a cigarette addiction you can't kick where every episode is like the puffs after the Thanksgiving Day meal.  If you hate the show, you're likely one of many who can't stomach the show for various reasons; its intelligence, honesty and raw power that oozes talent, sincerity and mastery of a broadcast medium that's long sunk into decadent masturbation.  Perhaps it's best you order the complete season of Friends or some other fantastically shallow show that makes it comfortable to be a simple couch potato who's forgotten that the world can be a little disturbing.

The Wire, since the first season, has been the most amazing show created in a long time.  In classic HBO form, it is very different in the way it stands out for its boldness, risk taking and iconoclast ambitions.  Every season seems to add more power and momentum to the greater themes of generational loss of the struggling people in our society, not only those in social perils, but ones who find themselves ethically and emotionally challenged by the political economic predicaments of the urban world and it's social hierarchy.

The perils, pitfalls and random incidents of modern bureaucratic failures  arrive at perfection in the writing, development, cinematography, and telling of stories all interwoven into a quilt of a collective drama.  No one has ever made a show about middle school children with so much depth and insight.  And this is not some "Stand By Me" barf bag of sentimentality that one can only relate to in a romanticized vision of childhood.  No, this is the honest and painful look at the lives of children who are forced to choose the path of lives only to be betrayed with the knowledge that their choices were premade for them and their hopes and innocence were a temporary reprieve from the reality of their urban hostility.

The story is not just Baltimore and the kids there but in all of the broken cities and communities all over this great and terrible country where the currency of hope will never catch the inflation of opportunity.  The story follows a group of 8th grade boys growing up in the dark world that the last 3 seasons have acclimated us for.  One by one, by random accidents or choices, their lives slip deeper into da' game where the cops, bureaucrats, and the street players await to indoctrinate them into the world most of us would prefer not to look.  The show is brilliantly acted and the kids are more than just believable, they're as real as we were at some point in our lives when the veil of innocence was still partially covering our view.

There's never been a show or movie aside from maybe "Fresh" that's been able to show us the story behind the induction into the world of street corner drugs, violence, and the thug life that seems to engulf our imagination but not our sympathies.  The Wire delivers this with the hard hitting punch to our teeth with emotionally stirring power that has become the signature of brilliance and horror.  The professional and local cast are seamlessly peppered (sorry Snoop, but girl, you're too flavorful) and are all amazing in the most spell binding storyline that I can only describe as being the greatest modern tragedy ever put on screen.

"Reality TV" is the fascination and sheer voyeuristic pleasure of watching petty emotional outburst in manipulated circumstances.  There is another reality that exists in the imagination that craves the essential and the necessary; the yearning for a mother's love, a child's hatred that desires murder, the knowledge of good pitted against the instincts to survive, and tragedy of not knowing the high price of exercise choice in  game where everything has consequences.  Such realities are offered in this show, without compromise, without apologies, and without the anesthesia of sentimentality.  Unlike traditional television with its familiar formulas, censored language and condescending themes that make us numb to what is real drama, this is a show that makes us question who we are and what kind of world we live in without allowing us to easily turn our heads away from the hard truth to the easy lie that is the story of America.
I love this show, every season I wonder if it can get any better and it does.

The fourth season continues with the amazingly excellent quality of the previous seasons. The acting is beyond superb - every character is portrayed so well you believe absolutely they exist. The script is perfect, the directing also, settings ... it simply is not to be missed. It's harder to watch than the other seasons, as it has more about the fallout of the drug scene on children and the part about the schools is real (we know well how "No Child Left Behind" has decimated what's left of inner city schools and this is an accurate portrayal) and therefore very difficult to watch. However, the outstanding quality of this series is worth it. We still can't believe something this spectacular is happening on television - although it has too much meat for a movie - it really has to be told over several hours and therefore on television - like a good novel written in chapters. With HBO making the bizarre decision to discontinue Deadwood, and the Sopranos having outlived its excellence before finally ending - if you want the best television can offer, this is the place to look for it. We tell everyone we know about it - it deserves to be watched by the biggest audience possible.
Ordered this with season 3.  Arrived at my home on exact promised delivery date in perfect condition, just in time for Christmas.  Highly satisfied!!!

The Wire is a great program, and I'd definitely recommend seeing the fourth season and the first three as well. It's still among the best and most involving things you can buy, and its comparable to HBO's best, including the Sopranos and Deadwood. And there are plenty of great moments and appealing characters in the fourth season -- Carcetti gets a lot more interesting and his campaign manager is a great character; Senator Clay Davis is funny as hell; Mayor Royce becomes a lot more interesting; there's plenty of Omar (always a good thing); and all of the new kids are great, especially Randy and Namond. Snoop, who carries the opening scene of the series, is great too. Prezbo wonderfully communicates the lost and helpless feeling of a novice teacher in the Baltimore school system. They are all great! One reservation I'd have though -- this show has started to get too preachy. Some of the speeches that Carcetti makes -- some of the speeches that get made in the middle school scenes -- some of the speeches that get made by the U. Maryland education reformers -- really start to get a bit too didactic. I know the show's creators have real situations in mind and want to get them across to the viewers, but they need to dial that stuff back *just a bit.* We get it. That's why we like the show. We don't need to have these points driven home so expressly, so literally. The other extreme, of course, is to become ever more elliptical and cryptic, as the Sopranos did in its later seasons. Its hard to walk the line, but I'm just putting that out there.

This is the best season of the best show on tv. The first three seasons were amazing, but the fourth, to me, was my favorite so far(the 5th and final season starts next month). Even though I take award shows with a grain of salt, it's criminal that The Wire gets no respect at all from them. I'm really going to miss this show.

The Wire is without a doubt the most realistic, daring, dimensional and layered of all of the HBO series. I've loved all of the HBO series, if for no other reason, for their honesty. I don't know if they have more artistic leverage or what, but they seem to be able to take more risks than most other television programs; consequently, character development is especially authentic. While some reviewers were completely turned off by the graphic realism of the characters and stories; having lived in Maryland for a few years, I can fully identify with the accuracy of the character portrayals. Having seen all four seasons, I think what turns some people off about The Wire is the realization that these horrors exist within the borders of arguably the world's richest and most talented nation. It also serves as a source that re-opens the wounds of subject matter long identified as on-going by some and self-imposed by others. And while the true ugliness of city life in Baltimore (or any other city for that matter) has been scaled back for the sake of television, The Wire does an exemplary job of capturing the struggles of life, love and betrayal; both personal and professional, in a politically forgotten, poverty stricken metropolis of American antiquity. By the way, the special features portion is especially revealing. The film, characters and its creators have developed a show that will, if not anything else, force you to ask critical questions pertaining to the implementation of capitalism. BRAVO HBO...BRAVO because this may very well be the best television program of all time!

This is the best show currently on television, and Season 4 of the Wire is the best season so far. Following the lives and journey of the new 4 young men was interesting and unpredictable as the season progressed. When you think you know where the show is going, it does a 180.

I have been a fan of this show since the very first season. I won't bore with a break down of this season, it has been done already. This season in my opinion, is the best so far. There are times during this season where I literally felt heart broken. This show has no signs the fatigue  most shows have at this point. It is still as relevant as ever. It is the best drama ever.

For me, the first few seasons of the Wire made for a good, uncensored cop show. But the show started scaling new heights, not just telling the stories of the cops and crooks, but of the schools, politicians and other institutions that surround them. By the time the Wire hit its fourth season, it was no longer a show about drug dealers- it was a show about the city of Baltimore, written by an ex Baltimore homicide cop and schoolteacher, and a former Baltimore journalist. On HBO, they've had the opportunity to tell the full story of their community, without censorship and no holds barred.

I just wanted to write this review to say that this season of this show is without a doubt the best television I have ever seen. It's realistic, gripping, mature, complex, riveting, heartfelt. The depictions of the drug trade that claims so many of Baltimore's inner city children is depressing, but the show also offers hope, finding the joy in life even as it confronts and depicts its darkest depths. I can't recommend this DVD set more.

The DVD is like 3hours long. It takes you into the life of Cormega, and what he's been up to for the past like 4-5 years. The soundtrack is fire, it's got Cormega, Styles P, Fame(M.O.P.), Hell Rell, Tragedy, AZ, Nature, Ransom and many others. BUY THIS CD\DVD AND SUPPORT MEGA MONTANA.

In season four the show becomes at times very hard to watch. There was always a great street excitement to it, nods to old west allusions (think of the near-gunfight with Omar in the alley last season with the bow-tie wearing Atlantic Monthly reading gangster from New York). But this year I wonder if they know they are winding down the show (season five will be the last) and so they want to get to the heart of how hopeless this world seems before they're off the air. The stuff in the schools will break your heart, as will the futility of things ever changing. But this is art, and probably the best TV show ever.

Don't worry, the wire is still one of the best shows on television,besides csi & sopranos, but get ready for some changes in Season 4. We see a bit less of some of our cast favorites and focus more on the race for Mayor and on the Baltimore school system.(None of what follows is a spoiler.) Mayor Royce makes a series of mis-steps, alienates the police high command, and gives white guy Tommy Carcetti a real chance of winning. Former cop Prezbuluski is now a school teacher and does his best to keep several new characters in school and off the corners. The major case squad is broken up and the cops are reduced to "rip and run" operations against minor drug dealers. Drug kingpin Marlowe may have found a way to get to Omar, who is still ripping off the major dealers. At first, I was a bit disappointed to see so little of the people I wanted to see more of, but then I realized that this show is going all the way - it's not just the cops and the dealers; it is the entire panorama of big city life....and death.

If you love sprawling epic novels like Middlemarch or Bleak House, you'll love the Wire. This is a stunningly intelligent, affectionate, sad, and angry portrait of Baltimore, its diverse citizens, and the institutions that fail them. The fourth season focuses on the (super-segregated) school system and is the best one yet. Its main characters start out as four funny 8th-grade boys in the inner city, and it tracks their perilous journeys into manhood. The adults in their lives are a very mixed bag, and even the well-intentioned ones can't always hold sway over the poverty, violence, and neglect in these children's lives. Everyone in America should watch this season and ask themselves how the richest country in the world can allow such horrors to happen to so many children.

The cast is huge, but my favorite Wire characters include Sgt. Carver, the exasperated cop trying to keep these kids safe and out of trouble; Mr. Prez, their novice, hapless math teacher who eventually learns to teach probabilities by letting the kids play dice; Cutty, the ex-con boxing coach, who tries to teach the boys how to fight with honor; and mayoral candidate Tom Carcetti, a wonderfully complex blend of smarts, sleaze, self-righteousness, and idealism. I can't think of another show with so many well-drawn and interesting characters. This is about as close to great literature as TV can get. Try it, you won't regret it! Tip: If you have trouble following the thick "Ballmer" accents, the closed captioning helps a ton.

Examining each link in the drug "food chain," this innovative HBO drama set in the thick of inner-city Baltimore includes everyone from junkies and dealers to cops and politicians. While the third season focused on the investigation of drug kingpin Avon Barksdale (Wood Harris), the show expands to tackle the urban education system's role in fueling the proliferation of drugs. Among the ensemble cast are Dominic West and Frankie Faison.

I was a little weary that Season Four would be watered down with the Middle School storyline but don't worry, it is incredible. I can't wait for January for Season Five live!
Hands down, the best show of all time.  Each season brings new and interesting characters and plot lines and is completely addictive.  I could not imagine how I watched television before "The Wire."

If you're reading this, you probably already know how great this show is, so I won't bore you with an episode breakdown. My topic for this review is regarding the packaging. As you may or may not know, previous seasons of The Wire had fancy digipack/book style packaging which may have been part of the reason the old MSRPs were so high. Luckily the MSRP for the new fourth season is lower, but comes with a serious drawback. This season is packaged in slim pack cases, which is fine...if it's done right. I have no problem with the fact that it's a different style and that it doesn't quite match previous seasons. My frustation is due to the fact that the actual slim pack cases do not elevate the discs high enough so they rub on the cases, causing scratches. The first disc in my set has pretty bad circular scratches and I have a feeling it will skip. The other discs are in OK shape (the fourth disc has minor scratches), but chances are you'll end up with at least one scratched disc. They could have avoided this had they just designed the slim packs better. I would rather them keep the cost higher and provide proper storage, rather than treating the discs with such carelessness. This show is too awesome to have it skip on you, and besides...if I pay for a new product, I expect it to look new. Thanks for cutting costs to protect your profit margin, HBO.

since it's beginnings four seasons' ago, 'the wire' has been a consistently excellent series. as one earlier reviewer stated
'the sopranos' doesn't even come close.the father of 'the wire' was
'homocide:life on the street' based on a book by david simon.
it ran on nbc from '93-'99.
this fourth season is the best so far, and it will be hard to top.
it was almost perfect!
by almost being the best drama on tv, imo, it's only barely beaten out by
'brotherhood'; showtime's awesome series that just concluded it's second
spellbinding season.
btw, with 'brotherhood' and 'dexter', showtime has passed hbo in quality original dramas.

As a math teacher, I have to say that this is my favorite season. I'm terrible at writing reviews and there are a lot out there, but I just wanted to say to anyone considering watching this show; start at season one and by the time you finish season four, you'll be in awe. This is, by far, the BEST show ever created. Sometimes it might seem a little slow or nothing significant happens, but you really have to consider all four (soon to be five) seasons as one. If you put the time into this show, it will repay you ten fold. Hope this helps.

Even the most dedicated fans of HBO's the Wire were left in awe of what this show brought us in Season 4.  This season focuses on 4 young corner boys in Baltimore's poor and drug infested Western district. We watch how the choices they make as middle schoolers forever seal thier fates in the high stakes world of the Baltimore street corners.  What unfolds is a fascinating  and sprawling tale that encompasses the world of the city drug trade. From it's heart on the street corners to the detectives and cops fighting the war against it all the way to the politicians in city hall and the state capital.  The stories move effortlessly from one set of characters to another and the end result is a pitch perfect masterwork.  There has simply never been a more accurate and compelling depiction of the urban drug landscape, it's players, and the endless cycle of violence and despair it causes than this season of this show. A 5-star marvel.

Season 4 of HBO's The Wire was nothing short of brilliant! This is a masterpiece; a visual novel where seemingly minor points and plots from each season are interwoven to create a complex, yet compelling story. For example, I loved how "the Greek" made a reappearance in one episode. I'll spare the season recap so that I do not ruin the experience for the new viewer, although caution, I do have a little spoiler below.

Like most of the other reviews, I agree that The Wire is by far, the absolute best television show, now or past. It puts the Sopranos, The Shield or any other television show to shame. It is intelligent and thought provoking, which is probably why it has never gained the wider audience or awards it deserves.

When the previews for Season 4 were initially released, I had my doubts. After the magnificent ending to Season 3 and the way Stringer was eliminated, I couldn't see how a story focused on the Bawlmore schools could live up.

As with the previous seasons, the story takes a bit of time to develop over the first few episodes. However, as I watched the tragic story of Namond, Michael, Randy, and Dukie unfold, I became yet again glued to my TV every Sunday evening. By the final episode of the season, it was evident that David Simon and Ed Burns had created a brilliant but sad masterpiece of storytelling. Season 4 by far tops the previous three in its power to move the viewer. In the final moment of the final episode, one wonders if Namond has truly escaped from the game.

I can not recommend Season 4 of The Wire enough, unless you first haven't seen Seasons 1 - 3. Without those, you may be a bit lost. Enjoy, but be prepared to be moved. I recently saw the crew doing some filming in suburban Maryland and I am anxiously awaiting the fifth and final season. I highly recommend!

This show is so good, it leaves you wanting more, I can watch an entire season in one sitting.

I just wish more people that I know watched this show so I can discuss the many great moments this show has. Too bad everyone I know just watches fauxality TV and has no idea what "The Wire" even is.

The Sopranos has been hailed as the sophisticated show to ever grace television, but it doesn't even hold a candle to the Wire.  A devastating, comprehnsive dissection of the decay of American cities and their institutions, the Wire is more comparable to a novel than any other medium.

The fourth season takes on the education system, while still following the drug dealers, cops and politicians from previous seasons.  And, moreso than past seasons, the results are devastating.

For the few people with open minds and good taste that have discovered "The Wire", I'm not going to continue to extoll it's virtues and throw out the "best show ever" line, as everyone who has had the chance to view any season in it's entirety already knows it truly is that.  This program has ruined me for network television, and has made me a true believer in HBO(hopefully they will continue to hit their water marks).
  All other crime dramas(law and order, CSI, etc.) seem postured, synthetic, and laughable.  No other program I've seen can or has illustrated the sociological turmoil and the despair within gut-wrenching drama, storytelling and brilliant dialogue like this.  But like all good things, this too must come to pass.  David Simon and co. have steadfast plans to end the saga after five seasons.  The fifth season I believe will start in Jan. 2008.
  No matter how good the show is, no matter how many people it has touched, no matter how much money HBO gives them for another season, it will not continue.  At first I was deeply saddened, but at least the show will go out on it's highest note, and will remain totally flawless(the fifth season is going to be the best, and most hard-hitting).

  For the last five to six years "The Wire" has been the best kept secret in broadcasting.  Like everything that is truly good in todays culture, it is criminally ignored except for the few people who have the patience to sift through the detritis that is modern-day tv.
  History of course, always reveals qualty to the masses, and I feel that it is an impossibility that this secret will forever remain a secret.  Years down the road, it will become a fixture in it's field; an icon of quality. I like the fact that "The Wire" has spread by almost total word of mouth through intelligent circles; That it has remained pure and un-exploited; that it hasn't become a fixture in pop-culture; that ignorant people ignore it to watch the meaningless, propagandized, consumer-driven schlock that is mainstream television; that it hasn't been reduced to an edited and "Family-friendly" form to be horribly misread; that the privelaged few who have seen any season of it recognize quality and perfection.
  But "The Wire" has achieved more than perfection, as the first season was definitely that.  Every season just gets better and better, and how do you surpass the status of perfection?  What on earth do you call it? That's easy.  You call it "The Wire"

The fourth season of 'the wire' sets a new standard for literature. This isn't just  the best show on television, it's right up there with the top titles in drama of all time. You either have to know inner city life intimately or you have to know your literature; for those in the latter category it might take all four seasons to fill you in on the venacular, but like shakespeare, once you fill it, you will be forever affected. If you are in the former category, you'll know how close this show gets to  reality. For those in both categories: you must watch this show.

Time and again HBO surprises with making even better shows but for now, this is the best. Us European taxpayers pay our state sponsored television organisations billions to produce this kind of television, but we never even remotely get this quality. For what I'm concerned I'd rather spend that money buying these kinds of HBO shows.

I own all seasons on DVD, and have watched them countless times. There is just so much to this show, it really is unlike any other. It is more of a novel then a TV show. At first things may seem slow moving but just keep watching, they reward you at the end, just like a book does. It's a perfect mix of drama, action, and comedy all wrapped into a magical show rich with metaphors and hidden messages. It's all there for you to interpret as you wish. It really is a shame that more people don't watch this show.

Part drama, part documentary. The most dramatically compelling American television ever, and the most socially relevant.

It will be a national tragedy if, as reported, the upcoming fifth season is in fact the last. I know the producers are saying that the inner city based subject matter has run its course, but I wish they'd stick with it.

Esta serie es pura dinamita!! Es FANTASTICA!!  Y la edicin es GENIAL! incorpora subtitulos en espaol, para los que aun no dominamos al 100% el ingls. Yo ya tengo hecha mi pre-order para diciembre. a qu esperas t?

I don't want to talk about the season that much because I don't want to give anything away.  Some reviews have and that's a shame.  But this is the best and most true to life TV series ever and never once falls into that male soap opera trap like the Shield or Sopranos or so many good dramas that just run out of realistic ideas. I heard the 5th season is supposed to be the last but I truly hope not.  It's one of those shows you want to go on forever.

I do believe that I have found the Holy Grail tele-drama equivalent! I would be content if there were no end to this incredible alignment of talented writing,acting,directing etc> just, can not say or view enough !!!Thank you to  everyone involved. This goes  even to the mailman who is going to deliver (my copy )!!!

I love t.v dramas. Especially police dramas. For years i thought N.Y.P.D. Blue was the best show ever. That show was just warming me up for something that would blow me out of the water. " The Wire" hands down is the best t.v. show ever. The fourth season is brilliant like the first three. I couldn't pick a season and say its the best one. That woulld be way to hard. That would be like picking out one of your kids and saying you love them the most. If you haven't seen the show, it is a little hard a first to "get it". When you watch it and give it a chance the reward will pay off. I have watched all four seasons of "The Wire" and there is not one wasted scene in the collection. A must see !!!!!!

It's criminal the amount of people that watch the best drama on television, "The Wire." I started watching because of David Simon. The man wrote the book that ultimately became my favorite TV show of all time, "Homicide: Life on the Street." I quickly became a huge fan, and theres a number of reasons why.

The writing for "The Wire" is nothing short of incredible. It's not written by "TV Writers" but more experienced authors and this makes quite a difference. A season of The Wire unfolds like a great novel. As each episode goes by, the greater the story builds. Its full of amazing characters and has many special touches and little nuances that are a joy to watch. The cast is fantastic and all the actors do a wonderful job.

I think what many people tend to miss is the importance of the storylines and the issues that David Simon and his team are addressing. In season 3 the storyline of Major Bunny Colvin "decriminalising" drugs in a certain area of his district was an amazing look at the world of crime and drugs. It was such an incredible storyline, because it wasn't black and white. An amazing hypothetical that leaves me thinking to this day.  This season they tackle the school system with even greater nous and intelligence.

The Wire is television at its very best, it also demands a lot from the viewer. It's definitely worth repeat viewing of the episodes. If you put the time in to notice the detail of the show it is extremely rewarding. The intricate storylines, complex characters, and revealing insights into life and institutions are waiting for your viewership. Season 4 of The Wire is the greatest season of the show.  Following the four young children throughout the season was truly heartbreaking.  If ever you wanted to own a show on DVD it's this one.  This will go down in history as one of the greats.

Despite having a small - but loyal - viewer ship, HBO keeps supporting this series.  The Wire is not easy at first - until you really get into it.  It's like a novel - you need time to relate to and understand the characters and story lines.  It's important to watch this series in sequence.  If you come in half way though, it will be very hard to get the most from the stories.  DVD is probably the best way of viewing the Wire.

I loved the first season of the Wire.  Omar in particular is a great character.  But they all are.  McNulty - that main character is probably my least favorite.

Season 2 was not as compelling.  The port theme was interesting, but I don't know.  I just didn't really find it as absorbing.

Season 3 - back into the season 1 storyline.  A great season.  The best of the first 3 probably.  Great twists and turns, and some really surprising turns of event.

Then comes season 4.  Very different from the others.  Based around city politics and the school system.  Season 4 was simply ones of the best pieces of television drama - ever.  The characters, the boys and their struggles, the race for Mayor.  I am looking forward to seeing it again on DVD so much.

Like the other reviewers, I also hope they keep on making the Wire.  I know they are doing season 5 - and HBO would usually wait for season 5 to start on the air before releasing season 4.  HBO must be wanting cash flow, having screwed up its schedule so badly - and canceling Deadwood and Rome (a***oles).  Let's hope they do season 6  and 7 and 8 and more ...

HBO also decreased the prices of the Wire DVDs.  If you have not seen the Wire -- take the opportunity.  If you have seen it, this will just be old news.
another work of art
Received as advertised
Bought for a friend to complete his "wire" collection - he's really happy with the series!

The Wire (2002-2008) is excellent. It paved the way for an even better drug crime show, Breaking Bad (2008-2013).

Most people are aware of corporate espionage and what some companies will do to protect their secrets. In the TV show Breaking Bad the two main characters, Walter White, played by Bryan Cranston, and Jesse Pinkman, played by Aaron Paul, possess the knowledge and skill to produce the best meth on the market. And their brand is easily identifiable by its unique blue color.

Several competing criminal organizations buy their services and try to replicate their product but Whites and Pinkmans skill in the art and science of making their blue meth product isn't easily duplicated. One group tries to hold Pinkman hostage in Mexico because their highly trained scientists cant make meth as well as he does. Near the end of the series another criminal group keeps Pinkman chained in their lab and force him to make meth for them because their guy, who worked with both White and Pinkman, is unable to duplicate Pinkmans and Walter Whites skill in the art and science of making their blue meth brand.

Breaking Bad has one of the best story and character arcs ever used in a TV show, which is why it has an IMDb rating of 9.5, right up there with Game of Thrones, another great show. The Wire (2002-2008) was as good as the Sons of Anarchy (2008-2014), but not as good as Breaking Bad. I won't give away the ending of Breaking Bad, but if you watch the complete series, from the first episode to the last, the ending will make complete sense and be very satisfying. Its terrific.

If the above series don't sound interesting here are a few of the series I really enjoyed watching more than once: Band of Brothers (2001), Battlestar Galactica (2004-2009), Black Sails (2014-2017), Cowboy Bebop (1998), Downton Abbey (2010-2015), Firefly (2002), Game of Thrones (2011-2019), The IT Crowd (2006-2013), Jericho (2006-2008), Lonesome Dove (1989), Lost (2004-2010), Merlin (2008-2012), Pride and Prejudice (1995), Rome (2005-2007), Spartacus: Gods of the Arena (2011), Stargate: SG-1 (1997-2007), Stargate: Atlantis (2004-2009), Star Trek The Original Series (1966-1969) and Star Trek Voyager (1995-2001). I didn't list any contemporary series Im following that don't have an end date yet, not conducive to binge watching from beginning to finish, or the hundreds of other fantasy and science fiction shows Ive watched.

If you like reading try some of my favorite authors: Richard Adams, Palo Bacigulupi, Suzanne Collins, Abe Evergreen, Diana Gabaldon, Hugh Howey, George Martin, Brandon Sanderson, John Scalzi, and Andy Weir.

Same review as the 3rd season. Provocative!!

Negatives: Too much time dwelt on the kids especially in the beginning of the season. Moreover, there are way too many characters to keep up with.
Plus: Tommy Carcetti's script is amazing.

Best Season of The Wire which means it is the ultimate in TV History. You might cry, you might cringe, you might sit on the edge of your seat. It is brilliant.
